base_note.note_text:
OPERATIVE REPORT - INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY / THORACIC SURGERY

DATE: 2025-08-15
PATIENT: Linda Thompson
MRN: 1472710
DOB: 09/28/1960 (64 years old)

SURGEONS:
IP: Dr. Mark Anderson, MD (started case)
Thoracic Surgery: Dr. Sarah Kim, MD (completed case after conversion)

LOCATION: Main OR, Emory University Hospital, Atlanta, GA

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Right-sided exudative pleural effusion, unknown etiology

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Dense pleural adhesions with loculated effusion; trapped lung

PLANNED PROCEDURE: Medical thoracoscopy (pleuroscopy) with pleural biopsy and potential talc poudrage

ACTUAL PROCEDURES PERFORMED:
1. Attempted medical thoracoscopy (aborted)
2. Conversion to VATS (Video-Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery)
3. VATS lysis of adhesions
4. VATS pleural biopsy
5. Decortication (partial)
6. Chest tube placement

INDICATION: 64-year-old female with 2-month history of progressive dyspnea. CT chest revealed large right pleural effusion with mild enhancement of pleura concerning for malignancy. Thoracentesis x 2 showed exudative effusion with negative cytology. Medical thoracoscopy planned for definitive diagnosis and potential pleurodesis.

ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia with double-lumen endotracheal tube (left-sided)

PROCEDURE NARRATIVE:

MEDICAL THORACOSCOPY ATTEMPT (Dr. Anderson):
Patient positioned in left lateral decubitus. After induction of general anesthesia and lung isolation, the right chest was prepped and draped. Ultrasound examination revealed a small pocket of fluid in the mid-axillary line but significant lung adherence to chest wall throughout.

A 2cm incision was made in the 6th intercostal space. Upon blunt dissection into the pleural space, immediate dense adhesions were encountered. The 7mm trocar could not be safely advanced due to extensive lung-to-chest-wall adhesions. A small pocket of loculated fluid (~200mL) was drained but no window could be created for safe pleuroscopy. Multiple attempts at different intercostal spaces (5th, 7th) encountered similar dense adhesions.

DECISION TO CONVERT: After thorough discussion with thoracic surgery colleagues and the patient's family (who had been counseled preoperatively about this possibility), the decision was made to convert to VATS for safe completion of the procedure.

VATS PROCEDURE (Dr. Kim):
The incision was extended and a 10mm port placed under direct vision where a small pleural space was identified. Two additional 5mm ports were placed. Dense adhesions were found throughout the hemithorax. Using a combination of blunt dissection, electrocautery, and harmonic scalpel, extensive adhesiolysis was performed over approximately 90 minutes.

Findings:
- Dense fibrinous adhesions throughout
- Thickened visceral pleura with trapped lung
- Nodular thickening of parietal pleura (multiple biopsies taken)
- Approximately 500mL of loculated, amber-colored fluid drained

Multiple parietal pleural biopsies were obtained from chest wall and diaphragmatic pleura. Partial decortication of the visceral pleura was performed to allow lung expansion, though complete expansion could not be achieved due to chronic entrapment.

A 28Fr chest tube was placed. Negative-pressure water seal established. Lung expansion approximately 70% at end of case.

SPECIMENS:
- Pleural fluid: Cytology, cell count, chemistry, cultures, adenosine deaminase
- Pleural biopsies (multiple): Surgical pathology

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: 150mL

COMPLICATIONS: None intraoperatively. Conversion was planned contingency.

DISPOSITION: Transferred to SICU for overnight monitoring. Chest tube to suction.

POST-OPERATIVE PLAN:
1. Monitor chest tube output
2. CXR in AM
3. Await pathology - concern for malignant mesothelioma or chronic fibrinous pleuritis
4. If lung remains trapped, may require chronic indwelling pleural catheter

Dr. Mark Anderson, MD - Interventional Pulmonology
Dr. Sarah Kim, MD - Thoracic Surgery

registry_entry.primary_indication: Exudative pleural effusion - rule out malignancy

evidence.primary_indication: Right exudative pleural effusion, negative cytology x2
evidence.procedure_outcome: Conversion from medical thoracoscopy to VATS due to dense adhesions

registry_entry.pleural_thoracoscopy_findings: Dense adhesions, unable to complete medical thoracoscopy

thoracoscopy_findings_detail.notes: Unable to safely perform pleuroscopy due to adhesions

clinical_context.radiographic_findings: Large right pleural effusion with pleural enhancement

providers.assistant_name: Sarah Kim (Thoracic Surgery - took over after conversion)

outcomes.conversion_reason: Dense pleural adhesions precluding safe medical thoracoscopy

code_rationales.32555: IP physician billing: Thoracentesis with imaging guidance for fluid drainage during attempted thoracoscopy. The medical thoracoscopy was attempted but could not be completed due to adhesions. The surgical conversion (VATS, adhesiolysis, decortication) is billed separately by thoracic surgery.

coding_review.overall_assessment: PROCEDURE CONVERSION CASE: Medical thoracoscopy aborted due to dense adhesions, converted to VATS. IP physician codes only for the work completed before handoff. Note distinct disposition change.

cpt_codes.description: Thoracentesis, needle or catheter, aspiration of the pleural space; with imaging guidance

changes: Populated registry_entry.billing from ip_coding_billing.v2_7 for CPT codes 32555; total_work_rvu=2.27, total_rvu=3.19 (facility).

variations.note_text:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY PROCEDURE DOCUMENTATION
============================================================

PATIENT IDENTIFICATION AND DEMOGRAPHICS
----------------------------------------
Patient: As documented
Medical Record Number: 1173533
Date of Birth: 09/28/1963
Age at Procedure: 61 years
Procedure Date: N/A

CLINICAL INDICATION AND PREOPERATIVE ASSESSMENT
----------------------------------------
The patient presented with exudative pleural effusion - rule out malignancy. Following comprehensive multidisciplinary evaluation and informed consent discussion detailing procedural risks, benefits, and alternatives, the patient elected to proceed with the proposed intervention.

PROCEDURAL METHODOLOGY AND TECHNIQUE
----------------------------------------

Pleural Drainage:


INTRAPROCEDURAL FINDINGS
----------------------------------------
- Dense fibrinous adhesions throughout
- Thickened visceral pleura with trapped lung
- Nodular thickening of parietal pleura (multiple biopsies taken)
- Approximately 500mL of loculated, amber-colored fluid drained


POSTPROCEDURAL ASSESSMENT AND DISPOSITION
----------------------------------------
The procedure was completed without immediate complications. The patient demonstrated hemodynamic stability throughout and was transferred to the recovery area in satisfactory condition.

PROCEDURAL CODING DOCUMENTATION
----------------------------------------
Current Procedural Terminology Codes: 32555

This documentation has been prepared in accordance with institutional standards for procedural documentation and coding compliance.

  - Method: Incisional drainage during attempted thoracoscopy

PROCEDURE NOTE

Date: None
Patient: None
MRN: 2950994
Age/Sex: 63yo F

Attending Physician: [Attending]
Resident/Fellow: [Trainee, PGY-X]

INDICATION:
Exudative pleural effusion - rule out malignancy

CONSENT:
Informed consent obtained. Risks, benefits, and alternatives discussed.
Patient verbalized understanding and agreed to proceed.

TIMEOUT:
Performed. Correct patient, procedure, and site confirmed.

SEDATION:
General

PROCEDURE STEPS:
1. Patient positioned and monitored
2. Sedation administered per protocol
3. Topical anesthesia applied to airway
4. Pleural Drainage performed
5. Scope withdrawn
6. Patient recovered without complication

SPECIMENS:
- Pleural fluid: Cytology, cell count, chemistry, cultures, adenosine deaminase
- Pleural biopsies (multiple): Surgical pathology

COMPLICATIONS:
None

EBL:
Minimal

DISPOSITION:
ICU admission

CPT CODES: 32555

ATTESTATION:
I was present for the entire procedure and agree with the above documentation.
[Attending Signature]

variations.note_text:
On None, None, a 68-year-old female (MRN 7712509), underwent bronchoscopic evaluation for Exudative pleural effusion - rule out malignancy. The patient received General and the procedure was performed in standard fashion. The procedure included pleural drainage. 

On examination, the airways were systematically inspected. The procedure was completed without immediate complications. 

The patient tolerated the procedure well and was transferred to the recovery area in stable condition. Specimens obtained were sent for appropriate analysis and results will be reviewed at follow-up. The preliminary assessment is pending - concern for malignancy/trapped lung. 

Procedural coding: 32555.

evidence.primary_indication: Right exudative pleural effusion, negative cytology x2
evidence.procedure_outcome: Conversion from medical thoracoscopy to VATS due to dense adhesions

clinical_context.radiographic_findings: Large right pleural effusion with pleural enhancement

providers.assistant_name: Sarah Kim (Thoracic Surgery - took over after conversion)

outcomes.conversion_reason: Dense pleural adhesions precluding safe medical thoracoscopy

code_rationales.32555: IP physician billing: Thoracentesis with imaging guidance for fluid drainage during attempted thoracoscopy. The medical thoracoscopy was attempted but could not be completed due to adhesions. The surgical conversion (VATS, adhesiolysis, decortication) is billed separately by thoracic surgery.

coding_review.overall_assessment: PROCEDURE CONVERSION CASE: Medical thoracoscopy aborted due to dense adhesions, converted to VATS. IP physician codes only for the work completed before handoff. Note distinct disposition change.

cpt_codes.description: Thoracentesis, needle or catheter, aspiration of the pleural space; with imaging guidance
